stream_context.summary: Kaze models and textures the overworld / Dino Domain area, focusing on closing mountain backdrops, re-working forests, and building a rainbow “miracle cave” while discussing optimization, asset pipelines and overall game progress.

development_findings.summary: Craft World is essentially finished; only a few elements are waiting on Biobak, and the following world (Space Civilization) is already complete.
development_findings.quote: The craft world is basically done… They actually already finished the world that comes after—that’s space civilization world.

development_findings.summary: The overall project is now “pretty close to completion,” with Kaze hoping for post-project “freedom.”
development_findings.quote: The game is actually like pretty close to completion at this point and then I will have my freedom.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is building the overworld’s mountain barriers, forests, and a rainbow spiral cave that signals a time-travel vibe for Dino Domain.
He solved a seamless 45-degree rainbow texture animation by calculating a √2×64 (~90.5 px) tile and layering two textures.
development_findings.quote: Shouldn’t it be like the square root of 2 multiplied by 64? … Yeah, okay, my intuition was right.

development_findings.summary: The forest currently looks unacceptable to Kaze; he requests new 2D+3D hybrid tree assets (≤16–18 triangles, 64×64 / 128×128 textures, sweeter Yoshi-like colors).
development_findings.quote: I need trees and I need a forest… These trees suck.

development_findings.summary: Pixelblahblah is producing new Mario animations, including a roller-coaster sequence that will become an in-game mission where the player can jump and eject.
development_findings.quote: Pixelblahblah has been making a lot of animations for Mario in this game.

development_findings.summary: Kaze demonstrates the Blender→decomp pipeline: model in Blender, export via Python script, import directly into Mario 64.
development_findings.quote: Blender lets you add any Python script… That goes into Mario 64.

development_findings.summary: He experienced severe editor lag (~3 FPS) but it resolved spontaneously; no fix was implemented.
He is considering adding Yoshi’s Island-style background pillars (“penisels”) and volcano-to-grass rock transitions.
Future plan: swap out all Mario IP and publish a Steam build, leveraging the re-compilation’s legality.
development_findings.quote: There’s a chance I will turn this into a non-Mario game… and put it on Steam.

context_findings.summary: Kaze felt dizzy all day and ended the stream early due to exhaustion.
context_findings.quote: I’ve been feeling super dizzy all day… I’m feeling pretty exhausted for today.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy: finish small mods first, only discuss design publicly if the project is a proven success.
context_findings.quote: I always tell people start with a small mod… If you make a bad game and then talk about your game’s design, that always feels super weird to me.

context_findings.summary: He strongly dislikes deliberately including bugs, even if famous glitches help a game’s popularity.
context_findings.quote: It just feels wrong to on purpose produce bugs.

context_findings.summary: He sees tight optimization as a potential marketing hook (“runs on real N64”) but notes that industry economics make heavy optimization rare.
context_findings.quote: Imagine the promotional power… we actually optimized our game so much it literally runs on a Nintendo 64.

biobak.summary: Responsible for remaining Craft World tasks and high-resolution textures; project progress currently waits on him.

zeina.summary: Briefly heard off-mic; no substantive project update.

key_stories.title: Tiling the Rainbow Cave
key_stories.summary: Kaze wanted a moving rainbow texture for the Dino Domain cave but couldn’t make it tile at a 45-degree angle. After trial-and-error he realized the tile must be √2 times the base size (~90.5 px) and layered two textures to achieve a seamless animation.
key_stories.challenge: A 45-degree rainbow pattern would not tile cleanly, breaking the visual effect.
key_stories.process: Experimented with different dimensions, rotations, and transparency, then calculated the exact size needed.
key_stories.outcome: Seamless, animated ‘miracle cave’ texture now works and matches the Yoshi’s Island vibe.
key_stories.key_quote: My intuition was right—square root of two times 64. Now this should work, right?

key_stories.title: The Forest That Still Looks Wrong
key_stories.summary: Kaze is unhappy with the overworld forest; existing trees clash with Yoshi’s Island aesthetics. He crowdsourced new hybrid 2D/3D tree models and set strict triangle and palette limits.
key_stories.challenge: Current forest assets look ‘really, really bad’ and break the game’s visual cohesion.
key_stories.process: Explained technical limits (≤18 tris, 64×64 textures, warmer ‘cotton-candy’ colors) and solicited models from chat artist Laura.
key_stories.outcome: Laura produced a draft low-poly tree (12 tris) that Kaze approved in concept; further iterations are pending.
key_stories.key_quote: These trees suck… It needs to be sweeter to fit into Yoshi’s Island.
